This couple currently owns a pumping machine that they use for their farming. In addition, they use their machine to pump water for nearby farmers' farmland for profit. They also plant corn as well as raise some pigs behind their house. 

Recently, her crop is not growing well because it lacks fertilizer. To improve this situation, Pheang N. has decided to seek a loan to buy some fertilizers for her crop. With part of the loan, she will also buy gasoline for the pumping machine.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, and gasoline for irrigation pump

loans.name: Perlina

texts.en:
This is Perlina S., 57.  SHe is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jesus S., a cook.  She is the mother of five children, one of whom is still in high school. By the grace of God, Perlina has managed to support her children's schooling.  At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Perlina, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Perlina operates a food stall where she alS. does side work like selling frozen cuts of spiced meat. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals in the evening when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. 

Perlina's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.   To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for Php 17,000. She will use the loan to buy more products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Perlina dreams to be able to have her own business stall soon. She alS. prays that the Lord will guide her family, especially her son who works as a seafarer. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy  more meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings

loans.name: Perlin

texts.en:
Perlin B. is from the town of Conat, Aloran. She is 30 years old and married, with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Perlin sells a variety of daily products in the local community.  Perlin has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

Perlin joined GDMPC this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlin is requesting her first loan, for 45000 PHP, to be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Cresilda

texts.en:
Mrs. Cresilda G. is from the Barangay of Lorenzo Tan, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married and blessed with 3 children  who are either still at their school and infant age. To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a bakery shop. She’s been engaged in this kind of retailing business for 2 years already. This time she is earning an amount of not less than Php5,000.00 from sales of this business. 

In the year 2009, Cresilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cresilda, as a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, is now requesting a loan of Php20,000.00 as her 1st loan which will be used as additional capital for her bakery shop business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, children’s education and possible business expansions.
	
 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her bakery business

location.town: Lorenzo Tan, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mind

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita S. is from the village of Gango, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 66 years old, married, and has four adult children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fifth taken out by Rosita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
This is Bernadette T., age 44 and resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Damaso T., a vendor, and together they have four children, all of whom are managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Bernadette has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Bernadette operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies in wholesale price and selling them at piecemeal rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more supplies of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Bernadette dreams that her business will continue to mature and be successful. She also prays for continuous physical and spiritual strength so that she may be able to continue her work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Jocelyn D. is from the Barangay of Garang, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, married to Bienvinido D. and blessed with 3 children of who are still at an infant age. To make a living, she is presently engaged in buy and sell business and managing a furniture shop together with her husband who is a sculptor. She’s been engaged in this kind of furniture business for 10 years already. At this time she is earning an amount of not less than Php14,000 from sales of this business. 

In the year 2009, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn as an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php40,000.00. She is now requesting a loan of Php50,000.00 as her 3rd loan which will be used for additional capital for their furniture shop business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, children’s education and possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for their existing furniture shop business

loans.name: Rodelyn

texts.en:
Rodelyn D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 44 years old. Rodelyn is married and has 2 children aged 18 and 10. To make a living, Rodelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rodelyn works hard to sustain her family and have savings in case of emergencies. 

Rodelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rodelyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as fertilizer

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon L. is a good homemaker who cares for the children and does housework. Mrs. Mon L. currently depends on the income from her husband’s work. He provides a well-digging service. His skill is digging wells by hand, and he has been working at it for years. He makes $7 a day to buy food for his family. Mrs. Mon L.’s husband has been very busy at his business as many clients need him to dig their wells. He is, however,  lacking materials to perform his service. Therefore, Mrs. Mon L. has requested a loan for his husband to purchase more digging materials.

loans.use: To purchase more digging materials.

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
This is Ma. Theresa M., 33, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Edward M., a foreman, and together they have three children all of whom are managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Theresa has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Theresa manages a silver jewelry business. Silver jewelry is very popular her in the Philippines because of its simple, casual appearance and because it is less pricey than gold jewelry yet has more value than costume jewelry. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php8, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more supplies of silver jewelry to be incorporated into her current product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Theresa dreams to be able to have more patrons soon, and she also hopes that her children will finish their education soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of silver jewelry to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Silma

texts.en:
56-year-old Silma P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has 4 children. She grows rice and raises pigs to earn a living. She and her husband plant and harvest rice crops. They have also used their backyard to start a small piggery. Silma raises the pigs to fatteni and sell. Silma said that maintaining the farm and piggery is quite a challenge but she does her part to grow their businesses and provide for the family.

Silma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Silma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Silma is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to buy rice seeds and pig feed.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and pig feed

loans.name: Lydia Villarubia's Group

texts.en:
Lydia V. is from the village of Catadman, city of Ozamis. She is 55 years old, married and has 1 school-aged and 3 adult-aged children. Lydia is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lydia V.’s Group.

To make a living, Lydia owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for ten years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. 

In 2006, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Lydia is requesting a new loan of14, 500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products for her retail store. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Maria Dolly from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

 About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note:
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

About Group Loans

In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or default.

loans.use: used to purchase additional products for her retail store

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Sok E., age 47, who lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 2000, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She has no life partner because she has been  divorced from her husband for several years. Sok E. has six children, five are single and one is married. 

Besides of this business, Sok E. is also a local farmer.s  She is not, however, planting crops on it yet. Sok E. hopes to use her Kiva loan to purchase seed and fertilizer to start the planting.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for growing.

loans.name: Zosa

texts.en:
Zosa L., from the village of Lower Dicayas, is 33 years old, married, and has three infant-aged children. Zosa operates a family member's business in the services sector, sewing and making dresses in the local community. Engaged in this business for over a year, she earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Zosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase materials and accessories for dressmaking activities, she is requesting her second loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase accessories for motorcycle repair. Zosa plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase accessories for motorcycle repair

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
This is Jennifer J., 34, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Bonifacio J., a factory worker, and mother of two children, both of whom are already settled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Jennifer has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send both of them all the way through college, a dream of most Filipino parents like Jennifer as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave their children.

Jennifer operates bicycle rental and flower shop businesses, earning at least Php4,000 per month from the rental of her bicycles and at least Php3,000 per month from her flower shop business. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.

To help continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a Php18, 000 loan to buy more quantities of fresh flowers to fill advance orders by her customers and to buy new bicycle units for renting. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Jennifer dreams of giving both her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her businesses. She also hopes to have more patrons who will regularly buy her products. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of fresh flowers and additional bicycle units

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena O., from the village of Galas, is 63 years old, married and has six grown children. Elena operates a family member's business in the retail sector, running a general store in the local community. Engaged in this business for over 10 years, she earns about 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to invest in expanding her business, she is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more goods for her store. This will be Elena's seventh loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchse additional goods for sari-sari store

loans.name: Koun

texts.en:
Koun K. is 30-year-old married woman and mother. She lives with other family members in her own small family home in Kompong Tom Province. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother, where she grows a rice crop. Her husband earns an income by selling firewood in the community, earning a profit averaging $2.50 a day. In this way, he shares financial responsibility with Koun K.. 

Koun K. is concerned that her old cow is too old to help her with the field work. So she is looking for a loan to buy a cow to replace the old one.

loans.use: To buy a cow to replace the old one.

loans.name: Zaydullo

texts.en:
Zaydullo D. was born and raised in the Republic of Tajikistan. He grew up in a large family and, from early childhood, he helped his parents in the field where his family cultivated vegetables. After serving in the army, Zaydullo returned home and began to work as a cinema operator.  He was 30 years old when he married, and he became the father of five children.  
In 1995, Zaydullo moved with his family to Kyrgyzstan. Using the money he had earned, he bought a house and started to work at the local state farm.  In order to find additional means of subsistence for his large family, Zaydullo decided to engage in cattle breeding and cultivating vegetables on the plot of land.  Using his starting capital of 3,000 KGS, he managed to raise his floating capital and earn 4,000 KGS monthly. Today, his farm has three bull-calves and still needs to be developed. For this purpose, Zaydullo plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to increase the number of cattle on his farm. Eventually,  Zaydullo plans to provide higher education for his children and build a house for his family. Being a very purposeful and positive person, Zaydullo works hard to support his family and provide them with a prosperous future.
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
This is Angie G., 42, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jaime G., a jail officer of the local penitentiary, and mother of three children, all of whom are still enrolled in elementary. By the grace of God, Angie has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Angie, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Angie operates an Electronic Cellular Phone Loading Station. What she basically does is to buy electronic cellular phone load in huge amounts then retail it to the customer. Profit is generated depending on the network's policy of dealership. She may buy 3,000 PHP worth of load for 2,500 PHP, where she already has a 500 PHP profit, depending on promos and quota set by the networks. Angie is also currently readying a few pigs for slaughter and operating a buy-and-sell business with a variety of products.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products to be incorporated into her buy-and-sell inventory. She will also invest some of the loan to buy electronic load from different local networks. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Angie hopes to be able to give her all her children a good quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more products for her buy-and-sell inventory and buy electronic load from different local networks

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
This is Nancy L., 54, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She has two children, one of whom is already working while the younger one stays at home and helps her in managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Nancy has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nancy operates a variety store, and as a sideline she is also raising a few hogs for slaughter. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for buying one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.60 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy a few more piglets to raise. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Nancy dreams of being able to stay physically, mentally and socially strong for her children. She also wants more pigs to raise and sell for meat. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia B. is from Upper Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She is 60 years old and married, and she has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a retail store, selling a variety of food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. 

Lilia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 3rd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Mrs. Tim S., 29, is a cake seller who, since early 2008, has been operating her business located in Kompong Tom province. She buys her ingredients on credit to make cakes, and pays after she finishes selling. She is able to generate about $3.50 each day to support the requirements of her family. 

Another source of family income comes from her husband’s job. He sells wooden beds that he has made himself. Currently, his business is going well, so he wishes to expand his business by buying some wood to make more beds to sell. This is why Mrs. Tim S. is requesting a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To buy wood for making beds to sell

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
This is Marcela G., 35, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Rey G., a security guard, and together they have three children, two of whom are already settled in school while the youngest is staying at home, toddling around. By the grace of God, Marcela has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marcela operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of about $4.75 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Marcela hopes that her children will finish their studies and have stable jobs. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Darwin

texts.en:
Mr. Darwin M. is from the Barangay (village) of San Antonio, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 33 years old, married and blessed with four children, two of whom are in school while the other two are still at infant age. To make a living, he is presently engaged in a piggery business. He’s been  in this kind of business for five months, and is earning an average amount of not less than $250 when the pigs are sold.

Just this year, Darwin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darwin, as a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP as his first loan, which will be used as additional capital for his piggery business, for purchasing feed and vitamins. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, children’s education and possible business expansions.
	

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

location.town: San Antonio, Ozamis City, Mis. Occidental

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
This is Remedios D., a 54-year-old resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has an offspring, a young adult who is already working and managing the household while helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Remedios managed to support her child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Remedios operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store retailing groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, Php5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a Php23,000 loan to buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

Remedios hopes that her business will grow and continue to be successful. She also prays that her family will be all right again. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, each fellowship group gathers every week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
This is Elena N., 50, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Edwin, a driver.  Together they work hard for a safe and secure future for themselves and their family.

Elena operates a meat business. Live pigs or meat are bought directly from hog raisers. The live pigs are then slaughtered, and then the meat is sold to members of the immediate community. Elena has many patrons who buy the cut meat and then sell it from their respective market stalls. There are many patrons who prefer Elena’s products because they are assured of its freshness and cleanliness. It is also a little cheaper to buy meat from an independent meat shop than the ones in the market who sometimes use the services of professional slaughterhouses for their meat. The cost of slaughter is added to the final price of the cut meat and passed along to the customers. Thus, Elena has many patrons who regularly anticipate her meat. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $10 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy live pigs to be slaughtered and sold every day. She also will invest a portion of the loan to buy pork, poultry and beef from other raisers.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Elena hopes that her business will continue to be successful, just as she fervently hopes that her children will be able to graduate one day, and be finished with their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy live pigs to be slaughtered and sold every day, and also to buy pork, poultry and beef from other raisers

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Adelaida A., 56, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nestor, and together they have two children, the older enrolled in college, the younger enrolled in elementary. By the grace of God, Adelaida has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Adelaida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of about $7 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 28,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Adelaida prays that her children will be able to finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Muong

texts.en: Muong S., 31 years old, lives with her family in the province of Kampong Chhnang in Cambodia. Her husband is a local farmer and they have five children. For over two years, she has been working in the rice trade business, collecting rice from farmers and re-selling it to earn income. She currently earns an average of $3.50 per day. She believes her investment is doing well because she is gaining more regular customers. This business is her main source of stable income for the family. In order to continue improving the business, she is asking for a loan to buy additional rice to sell in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional rice to sell in the future.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
To reach high goals, you must first dream big and plan big time. Melanie R. of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines, 34, knows this and applies it in both her personal life and business. Melanie is married to Normelito, who operates a buy and sell business, and together they raise three children, one of whom is in high school, while the other two are in elementary.

Melanie manages a wet junk shop and another junk shop for dry items. With four years of experience, she runs it well and knows which strategic plans to implement to make her business grow. Melanie presently has six employees to help her with the daily tasks. Monthly, she earns a net income of around Php10,000.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan to keep her business in good financial health. Melanie also intends to implement her plan to acquire a commercial space in Waterhall and a delivery truck for her junk shop. Melanie faithfully attends her weekly group fellowship* meetings facilitated by CCT staff.

Melanie still has to recover from the impact of the disastrous typhoon Ondoy on her business. She also has to cope with the physical challenges posed by high blood pressure. Despite these challenges, she has not given up her ambitious goals which include building her own house and acquiring a motorcycle with a sidecar. She also wants to buy her children a computer which they can use for their studies. Most of all, she dreams of seeing her three children finish school with high academic achievements.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, each group gathers every week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase junk shop facilities

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en:
Chhim S. is a married woman who is 39 years old. She has been a farmer, a skill she learned from her grandmother, for years. She plants rice to make a living. 

Her husband is a local palm climber who taps palm juice and turns it into palm sugar for selling. Besides this business, she and her husband are firewood buyers, which they resell for profit. 

This couple was married many years ago and has three teenage children. Their children attend school and also help them on the farm when they are free from their classes. Chhim S. needs a loan to buy additional firewood for selling, and the rest of money will be used to purchase a ladder for her husband to use for climbing palm trees.

loans.use: To buy additional firewood for selling, and to purchase a ladder for her husband to use for climbing palm trees.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina A. is from the village of Mimbunga, Gingoog City. She is 27 years old. Cristina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cristina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling fish, such as sardines and mackerel in the local community. She also buys and raises pigs for future sale. Cristina has been engaged in her business for more than seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cristina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP. which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Cristina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
