Touch N. will be using her loan to invest in her business to buy more baskets to sell.

loans.use: To buy more baskets to sell.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon K., 28-years-old, runs a retail shop in Kiwanja. He is married to Ann Mutile and together they have one child. He has been running his shop for 2 years and his monthly profit is 15,000 KSH.

He was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Thika Road office. This loan of 70,000 KSH is Simon's third loan with KADET and he intends to increase the inventory of sugar, wheat, flour and rice in his store. He hopes that the loan will boost his business, so that he can expand it and increase the standard of living of his family.

Simon plans to open a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to increase his inventory of sugar, wheat, flour and rice

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en: Myagmarsuren D. is 33 years old and lives with her husband and two children in an apartment Tuv province in central Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends a local secondary school. Her husband operates an international cargo service between Korea and Mongolia. Myagmarsuren used to work as a programmer in the health agency between 2000-2006 after graduating from agriculture university in 1998. In 2009, she and her husband both went to Korea to work there in order to make more money. After returning to Mongolia in 2010, her savings earnings have enabled her to purchase an apartment and a new car for her family. She currently operates a clothes and cellphone trading business in her town. She started her clothing business in August, 2010 by selling a variety of clothing items and cellphones and its parts in the local trade center. Myagmarsuren plans to expand her business by offering computer related services to her customers. In order to operate this business, she needs to purchase and place a computer, camera and printer next to her stall at the local market. For the future, she hopes to continue to grow her business and open her own trade center with her business profits. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase computer, canon and printer in order to start providing new services.

loans.use: To purchase a computer, a camera and printer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying sugar, soap and soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne A., aged 26 years, hawks African materials, table cloths and seat covers around Mbotela Estate in Nairobi and along Jogoo road. She is married to Gilbert Wemani and together they have two sons: Peter, aged 7 years, in primary school, and Franklin aged 2 years. She has been running this business for 3 years and her monthly profit is Kshs 9,100.

She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. This loan of Kshs 20,000 is her first loan with KADET. She intends to use Kshs 15,000 to buy 10 pieces of African material and Kshs 5,000 to buy table cloths, all for resale. If this loan boosts her business, Everlyne will buy more stock to expand her business, which will enable her to educate her son.

Everlyne dreams of opening a shop to sell her materials from instead of hawking. She describes herself as humble and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy African material and table cloths to sell

loans.name: C2159 Abadahemuka Group

texts.en:
Dative is 48 years old and married with four children between three and 17 years old. She is the president of a group called “Abadahemuka” and she sells bananas. This is her 4th successful year in this business, which she operates from 6 am until 6 pm every day.

Dative will use this loan to purchase a large quantity of bananas to sell at the market. With this expansion, Dative hopes her profits will increase. She plans to use these to provide food for her family, pay school fees, save for the future and reinvest further in her business.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of bananas.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth L. is from the town of Banga. She is 52 years old and married with three children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns a business planting and harvesting rice and corn and vegetables to sell.

Elizabeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Zina's Group

texts.en:
Dairy farming has always been successful in Kyrgyzstan. Today, Kyrgyz milk products can honorably compete with such giants in the dairy industry as Germany and Russia.  The largest consumers importing milk products from Kyrgyzstan are the neighboring Central Asian countries. 


Zina I., 42, is a leader of this group. She is a cook in a local milk-producing company “Sut Bulak”. Having worked there for a long time, she understands the whole process of dairy farming. Zina claims that the dairy process begins with taking good care of the dairy cattle.  Eight years ago, Zina and her husband, a farmer, decided to spend a month's salary on the purchase of cattle.  Although at that time 6000 Soms were enough to purchase cattle in the market, today cattle costs a large amount of money. Zina and her group applied for a Kiva loan in order to broaden their  business. Zina hopes to get a loan to buy additional cattle. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel N., aged 40 years, hawks household items like basins, buckets, cups, sufurias (pots), and CDs around the Mwiki area. He is married to Eunice Wambaire, who runs a green grocery shop to financially support their family. Together they have three sons: Antony, aged 15 years, Newton, aged 13 years, and Brian, aged 11 years. He was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Thika Road office.

Samuel has been running this business for a period of 12 years, and makes a monthly profit of Kshs 8,000. This loan of Kshs 18,000 is his second loan with KADET. He plans to use the loan to add stock of sufurias (pots), plates, basins and buckets. If the loan boosts the business, he will rent a shop and stock his goods there instead of hawking.

Samuel hopes to become a supplier of household goods and to employ young people as salespeople.

loans.use: To stock CDs, sufurias (pots), and cups for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy firewood for sale

loans.name: Joseph Muoki

texts.en:
Joseph is 61 years old and married to Pascalia who is a house wife. He buys livestock, fattens them and then sells them to make a profit. He has been in the business for a period of 30 years, with an income of Kshs. 20,000 per month.

This is his third loan from KADET LTD, after successfully repaying the previous two. He hopes to be a leading livestock trader, give his children a quality education, and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy more cattle for sale

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica S., aged 43, supplies snacks to Umoja Estate shops. She is married to Joshat Mutunga and together they have 3 children: Mawia, in University, Kithae, in form four, and Nzambi, in form one. She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

Veronica has been running this business for a period of 9 years and her monthly income is Kshs 30,000. This loan of Kshs 25,000 is her second loan with KADET. With the loan she will increase stock of biscuits, popcorn and sweets for supply. If the loan boosts the business, Veronica will open a wholesale shop since she supplies from shop to shop.

Veronica dreams of expanding her business to enable education of her children and to finish building her house. She describes herself as hardworking and social.

loans.use: To increase stock of biscuits, popcorn and sweets for supply

loans.name: Sourng

texts.en: Sourng H. is 68 years old.  She lives with her child in Kompong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Her husband died many years ago from illness. Sourng H. currently generates an income of approximately $3 per day by selling Khmer cakes in her village. Her Khmer cakes are very good and she sells them well almost every day.   Sourng H. is requesting a loan to use as additional capital to buy raw materials to make Khmer cakes.

loans.use: To buy materials to make Khmer cakes to sell

loans.name: Erminio

texts.en:
Erminio P. is from the village of Benito, Soliven, Isabela. He is 36 years old. Erminio is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Erminio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Erminio has been engaged in this business for 10 years and earns approximately 30000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Erminio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erminio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  Erminio is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Erminio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius C., age 45, runs a sugarcane wholesale business at Shauri Moyo estate. His customers are small-scale buyers who sell in the streets and to traveling passengers. He is married to Peninah and together they have two children, Carol, age 17, and Peter, age 14. Julius was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

Julius has been running this business for a period of 5 years and his monthly profit is 18,000 Kenyan shillings. This loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings is Julius’ fourth loan with KADET. He plans to buy two lorries of sugarcane for his wholesale business. If the loan boosts the business, Julius will add more stock and provide better living standards for his family. He will also pay school fees for his children.

Julius dreams of getting tenders from sugar mills. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy two lorries of sugarcane for his wholesale business.

loans.name: Moses Mungai

texts.en:
Moses has operated a boutique shop in the town of Naivasha for the last year. He is 34 years and is married to Nancy Gathoni. They are blessed with two school children. 

Moses was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his third loan, and he paid his previous loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings in full and in good time. He plans to use the loan boost his stock of clothes in his shop to cater to the high demand during the festive season. In the future, Moses hopes to expand his business and stock clothes and shoes of all fashions.

loans.use: To boost his stock of clothes in his shop to cater to the high demand during the festive season.

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya U. is 27 years old.  She lives with her husband and two daughters in Tuv province in central Mongolia.  She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent, called a ger, on a small plot of land which they own for the past 10 years. Her oldest daughter attends a local primary school and her youngest daughter is in kindergarten. 

Sarantuya operates a clothes making and repair business in her town. She started her business in 2000, at first sewing only traditional Mongolian coats called deels. After years of successful operation, she was able to buy the necessary tools and equipment such as a  zig zag sewing machine, a multifunctional sewing machine, and a steam iron, which enabled her to make not only traditional clothes but also European style clothing. 

Sarantuya is a hardworking and honest woman. For the future, she plans to have her own sewing factory. She is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more materials and supplies for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials and supplies

loans.name: Suidumkan's Group

texts.en:
On December 13th 2010, high school and middle school teachers in several regions of Kyrgyzstan held protests against the Ministry of Education. Their main concerns were the low salaries being paid, which led to a lack of teachers in schools and a low quality education for students.  Why has one of the most important professions such as teaching become one of the least paid jobs?

Suidumkan B. is a leader of this group.   The low salary for teachers made it inevitable for her to start her own  business. In 2000, Suidumkan and her husband, a forester, applied for a loan at a local bank.  The 20,000 soms loan and some of her savings allowed Suidumkan to start a business in cattle breeding. The family business gave them the opportunity to purchase a car  – an old Russian “Jiguli”  model, which helped cut some  transportation expenses.  Unfortunately, 3000 soms of monthly income is too little, so they applied for this loan in order to purchase 12 heads of cattle.  

Suidumkan and her group is thankful to Kiva and all lenders, who are not indifferent to changing their lives. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase 12 heads of cattle

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter W., 37 years old, runs a cosmetics shop in Njiru. His Njiru market is on the outskirts of Nairobi so many people buy from Peter rather than making the trip to the city. He is married to Margaret and together they have a daughter, Joy, 10 years old. Peter was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

Peter has been running this business for 10 years and his monthly profit is 16,000 KSH. This loan of 40,000 KSH is his second with KADET and he intends to use 10,000 KSH to buy hair relaxers, 20,000 KSH to buy hair bands, and 10,000 KSH to buy perfumes for sale. If the loan increases the business, Peter will be able to expand his inventory and increase his profits. This will enable him improve the living standards of his family and educate his daughter.

Peter dreams of opening a cosmetics wholesale shop in the future. He describes himself as aggressive.

loans.use: to buy hair relaxers, hair bands and perfumes for sale

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
34-year-old Ivy G. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has a 2-year-old child. She grows rice and raises pigs and ducks. She and her husband till their farm where they plant and harvest rice crops. They sell their harvest to the market and use some for family consumption. They also use their backyard to grow pigs and ducks. Ivy fattens the pigs and sells the duck eggs.

Ivy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ivy is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to buy farm supplies and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feeds

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John M., aged 39 years, operates an auto spares shop at Kirinyanga Road in Nairobi city center. He is married to Sarah and together they have two children, Dan and Jane. He has been running this business for a period of 5 years and his monthly profit is Kshs 8000. 

He was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. This loan of Kshs 40,000 is John’s first loan with KADET. With the loan, John plans to use Kshs 30000 to buy clutches and wheels and Kshs 10000 to buy motorcycle spare parts. If this loan boosts the business, John will increase his stocks to expand his business further.

John's dream for the future is to open another shop and a garage. He describes himself as hard-working.

loans.use: To buy clutches, tires, and motorcycles spare parts.

loans.name: C2899 Dufatanye Group

texts.en:
Rose is the president of a group called “Dufatanye” who have a total of four members, each with a different business.   Rose owns a small general store which sells different kinds of products.

Rose is 40 years old  and is married with three children. Her husband is a driver and they both work hard for their family.   Her business is open from six in the morning until six in the evening every day, including weekends. This is her 6th successful year in her business.

Rose will use this loan to purchase more products such as salt, cassava flour, bread, and so on.  Rose has many plans for any profits that she makes from this loan.  She would like to provide food for her family, pay school fees for her children, renovate her house, save money for the future, as well as purchase more stock for her store.  A long list!

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: John Wairitu

texts.en:
John is 47 years old and married to Lucy Njeri who is a farmer. They have two children. He runs a transport business in Thika town. He has been in the business for a period of 10 years with an income of Kshs.30,000  

This is his first loan from KADET LTD and John plans to top-up his savings and buy a new PSV vehicle (Matatu). He hopes to have a fleet of cars and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To top up his savings and buy a new PSV vehicle (Matatu)

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en:
Gerald M., aged 34 years, runs a Taxi business at EastLeigh Estate which is a densely populated area. He is married to Pauline Wanja and together they have two children, Geoffrey and Winnie both in primary school. He has been running this business for a period of 9 years and his monthly profit is Kshs 20000.

He was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients and the loan of Kshs 60,000 is his third loan with KADET. He plans to use the loan to purchase tires for his car. If this loan helps boost the business, Gerald will open a business selling second-hand shoes.

Gerald’s dream is to have a fleet of taxis in the future. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his taxi.

loans.name: Tursunoi's Group

texts.en:
The Southern part of Kyrgyzstan is proud to have rich land for cultivating many crops. Agriculture is so important in the economy of the country that even the national emblem displays wheat and cotton, known as “white gold”.  Along with wheat and cotton, other cultivations are being developed such as vegetables, fruits, and grains.

Tursunoi N., 53, is the leader of this group. She has been active in farming for fourteen years. At this moment she’s getting ready to prepare land to plant potato seeds.  Tursunoi started the farming business fourteen years ago with wheat cultivation on land that she possessed after the privatization. She invested 890 soms into her business start-up, which was a rather significant amount at that time. Now she earns an income of 3900 soms every month. She hopes to obtain this loan to purchase fertilizers and potato seeds. Tursunoi’s sons are in Russia at this moment, and promise to assist her financially so that she will be able to repay this loan. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and potato seeds

loans.name: Khaticha's Group

texts.en:
Microfinancing is very useful in improving social living in Kyrgyzstan.  People who are in need of financial assistance are tired of high interest payments to local banks. Kiva has become a blessing for thousands of families throughout the country, and is making confident steps for further development into the future.

Khaticha A., 42, is a leader of this group. She is a farmer in a small southern village called Aravan.  This has become a lifetime occupation for her, since she has been farming and staying close to nature from early childhood.  At this moment, Khaticha is working on preparing land for cultivation. Her husband works in construction and electrical maintenance. Her children are all dependent on this  family income, including the youngest one, who is 10 years old. Khaticha also has to take care of arranging a wedding ceremony for her oldest daughter. 

Khaticha’s group looks forward to having this loan and maintaining each one’s own business.  With this loan, Khaticha plans to purchase fertilizers and pay transportation bills. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers & pay transporation bills

loans.name: Arzu

texts.ru:
Arzu H. 32 qoda. On jenat imeyet 2 detey.Doch kotoroy 7 let uchitsay v shkole i doch kotoroy 5 let xadit v detskiy sad. Azru I yeqo semya  jivut v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Arzu uje 4 qoda kak yavlyayestsya voditelem betonomeshalnoy mashini.  Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya svoyey mashini. Arzu etomu biznessu nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca kotoriy  toje bil voditelem.
texts.en: Arzu H. is 32 years old. He is married with two children: a 7-year old daughter, who goes to school, and a 5-year old son, who is in kindergarten. Azru and his family live in the Absheron Region. For about four years, Arzu has been a cement truck driver. At present he needs 2,000 AZN in order to buy spare parts for his truck. Arzu learned his business from his father, who also used to be a driver.

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for his truck

loans.name: Kimatu

texts.en:
Kimatu is 51 years old, married to Esther who is a housewife and together they have six children. He sells new clothes in Wote, Makueni. 

Kimatu was introduced to KADET LTD by friends who were already members. Kimatu has been running the clothes business for two years and this is the second loan he is getting with KADET and he intends to use it to purchase more clothes for sale considering that this is the festive season and he is likely to get better sales than other seasons.

If the loan improves the business, he desires to open a real shop of his own and move from the market stall which is only semi-permanent.

loans.use: Kimatu plans to buy more clothes for sale, especially in the festive season.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Transportation is a vital issue in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. There are many ways for a customer to get from point A to point B. The most wide-spread is a mini-bus, which can seat 12 people. There are also many trolleys, buses, and city cabs.  In order to make a living, many offer a private cab service, where a customer and a cab driver can negotiate the price.

Aigul K., 43, is a leader of this group. Her husband, like many others, works as a private cab driver.  Aigul appreciates her husband’s hard work and tries to make her own contribution to the family budget. Aigul has a dairy cow, which can yield 20-30 liters of milk per day. She delivers fresh milk to customers.  In 15 years, this has turned into a very promising business. 

They have four children.  Her daughter was accepted into medical school and Aigul is very happy for her daughter’s future.  Aigul earns a monthly profit of 8800 soms from her business, which goes to buying food for the cattle. Aigul and her group applied for a loan in hopes of improving their lives. Aigul would like to purchase furniture for her house and believes she can repay the loan successfully. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase furniture

loans.name: Edith Atieno

texts.en:
Edith Atieno N. is 30 years old, married to Thomas Wapas who is a clinical officer and is also a source of additional income for the family. They have three children attending school of age five years, three and one years. Their residence is in Lodwar-Kenya. She has been operating a boutique and has been in this business for two years and earns a monthly profit of KES.30,000.

Edith learned about KADET LTD through a credit officer and so she is applying for her first loan of KES.40,000 from KADET LTD, which she intends to buy varieties of clothes. With the anticipated profits, she plans to boost up her business and put up a rental house.

In the future, Edith wishes to live a better and more comfortable life with her family.

loans.use: To buy a wide variety of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sabougnouma  (La Bonne Cause) Group

texts.fr:
Sabougnouma est un regroupement de six femmes, toutes mariées, du quartier Hamdallaye de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles ayant en moyenne 38 ans et 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, le  bois de chauffe, les habillements,  les fruits et légumes, les céréales, du poisson, le savon, etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Tata Dembélé  est un membre du groupe Sabougnouma qui vend du riz, des poissons fumés et des fruits et légumes.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des fruits et légumes à Koutiala, du riz et des poissons fumés à Yangasso. Elle vend du poisson et du riz en détail et au comptant au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle diverse et variée. Quant aux fruits et légumes (carottes, bananes et mangues etc), ils sont vendus au marché de  Yangasso.
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 110 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Tata Dembélé compte réaliser 130 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent renforcer leur partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne manquent plus.
texts.en:
Sabougnouma is a group of six women, all married and from the Hamdallaye area of Koutiala, who live in traditional extended households and are, on average, 38 years old with 4 children.
This group of women runs businesses selling various items such as firewood, clothing, fruits and vegetables, cereals, fish, soap, etc.
To increase the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners) two years ago. They are on their third group loan, and both the previous loans were repaid properly.
Tata Dembélé is a member of the Sabougnouma group and sells rice, smoked fish, fruits, and vegetables.
She intends to use this loan to buy fruits and vegetables in Koutiala and rice and smoked fish in Yangasso. She sells the fish and rice at retail and in cash at the grand market in Koutiala to a diverse and varied clientele. As for the fruits and vegetables (carrots, bananas, mangoes, etc.), they are sold at the Yangasso market.
While the members of the Sabougnouma group each hope to realize a monthly profit of 110,000 FCFA throughout the loan cycle, Tata Dembélé intends to realize a profit of 130,000 FCFA.
In addition to repaying the loan, these women will use a portion of their income to meet their current family needs.
They hope to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure that their stocks are never lacking.

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
The average Kyrgyz family has three children.  Since old times, Kyrgyz  families tended to have six or seven children. The reason for that is the strong family ties and sense of family identity of a Kyrgyz family.  And, they simply just love children. Urban families now usually stop at a third or fourth child, but rural families still follow the old Kyrgyz culture and like having big and friendly families. 


Gulnara I. is the treasurer of this group.  She is a forty-seven-year-old resident of Kochkor, a small town in northern Kyrgyzstan.  She has a big asset:  six children. The youngest child is now a senior in high school. Gulnara proudly claims that raising six children was her greatest accomplishment. She feels fulfilled in helping them find their own place in life. 

Gulnara and her husband are skilled farmers. They say land is always the only source of income and they cannot imagine life without farming, because it’s what they have been doing their entire lives. Along with farming, the family raises and sells cattle. The family started the business fifteen years ago with only 10,000 soms. Now they have 10,000 in monthly profit.   But because of inflation, this amount is not enough to purchase additional cattle and to advance the business. Gulnara hopes to get a loan in order to promote her business. Time will show if she will be able to build the house of her dreams. 


  --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Rosa's Group

texts.en:
After the collapse of the Soviet Union, fifteen small republics, including Kyrgyzstan, were left to survive on their own and struggle with economic instability.  Collective farms, which worked only for the government, stopped functioning. The process of “privatization” started. Families were given land according to the number of people in a family. Private businesses of cattle breeding and farming took place in the end of 20th century. Rosa I.’s family also became land owners and their own story began. 


Rosa I. is the treasurer of this group.  Rosa and her colleagues formed a group when applying for this group loan. Rosa’s group members are not only close friends, but each of them is also a professional in farming. All of them are residents of a small town called Kochkor in northern Kyrgyzstan.  Fifty-two-year-old Rosa is the most experienced of the group.  She has been involved in farming for at least fifteen years. 

Rosa is a proud mother of six sons and two daughters.  Her youngest son, a junior in college, is the only one still dependent on Rosa. Rosa and her husband, who is also a farmer, received land in 1995 and started cultivating it. This occupation brought enough revenue to purchase cattle and additional land in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan.  Now the family is hoping to get this loan to purchase more cattle, and spend the proceeds on a gift for Rosa’s husband:  a long-waited automobile. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien. Elles vivent ensemble dans le même quartier, dans de familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris et enfants. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, sont mariées et mères de 4 enfants.
La majorité des femmes du  groupe Danaya fond de la teinture et vente de bazins, de chaussure.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Daly K. qui est un des membres fait l’achat, la teinture et la vente de bazin Elle est très sollicitée car elle a du talent  en dehors de ses vente elles reçoit fréquemment des clients pour des services.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des pièces de bazins et des colorants. Elle se procure de ces marchandises au  grand marché de Koutiala en gros pour  revendre l’article fini c’est à dire les bazins teints en détail au comptant  et a crédit à une clientèle  diverse et variée.
Tandis que Les autres membres du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Daly K.  elle,  compte réaliser  65 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles ambitionnent renforcer leur partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso afin de consolider leurs activités.
texts.en:
Danaya is a group of women from the Hamdallaye area of the city of Koutiala who know each other well. They live together in the same area, in traditional households with their husbands and children. They are on average 30 years old, married, and have 4 children.
The majority of the women in the Danaya group dye and sell bazin fabric (a type of damask) and shoes.
To increase the size of their businesses, the group members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners).
One of the members, Daly K., buys, dyes, and sells bazin fabric. She is highly sought-after because she is talented. In addition to her sales, she also frequently receives clients for fabric services.
She intends to use her loan to buy pieces of bazin fabric and dyes. She procures these goods at the grand market in Koutiala at wholesale, and then sells the final articles - the dyed bazin fabric - at retail, in cash and on credit, to a diverse and varied clientele.
While the other members of the Danaya group each intend to realize a monthly profit of 55,000 FCFA throughout the loan cycle, Daly K. herself intends to realize a profit of 65,000 FCFA.
In addition to repaying the loans, they use a portion of their income to meet the current needs of their families.
They aspire to reinforce their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to strengthen their businesses.

loans.use: To buy bazin (damask) fabric and fabric dyes

loans.name: Peter Mburu

texts.en:
Peter is 46 years old, married to Philis Wairimu a business lady. They have three children. He has been in the transport business for a period of 15 years with an income of Kshs. 45,000 per month. 

This is his first loan from KADET LTD and he wants to use it to top up his saving and buy another passenger vehicle, or Matatu. He hopes to expand his business and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To top up his savings and buy another passenger vehicle(Matatu)

loans.name: Nadya

texts.en:
Nadya G. lives in Gandzakar village, in the Ijevan area. She is married and has 3 sons. 

One of Nadya's sons helps her run a flower trading business, which Nadya has been managing since 1994. She runs her business from a rented stall in the Ijevan central market, where it is always very populous. 

Thanks to the business income, Nadya was able to support her family and buy a car for her business.  Having a car has made delivering flowers from Yerevan to Ijevan easier, and has cut down her business costs.    

Unfortunately, recently Nadya and her son had a little accident.  Now Nadya is asking for a 600,000 AMD loan to repair their car, which is very necessary for them in their business.

loans.use: To repair car, used for flower delivery

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John K., age 32, operates a well-stocked general shop at Kingstone Estate. He is married to Zepha Kemunto and together they have three children, Teresa aged 11 years in class 5, Robert aged 8 years in class 2 and Irene aged 3 years. He was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

John has been running this business for 10 years and his monthly profit is Kshs 45000. This loan of Kshs 81000 is his second loan with KADET. With the loan he will buy a motorbike to start a motorcycle transport business. If the loan boosts his income, John will buy another motorcycle and employ someone to operate it. 

John’s dream is to buy a piece of land and build a house to live in with his family. He also plans to educate his children to university level. He describes himself as polite, hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle and start a transport business

loans.name: C2160 Cophecomba Group

texts.en:
Leoncie is the representative of a group called Cophecomba.    Leoncie owns a small shop selling green bananas, which she has had for one year.  She employs one person to help her manage the business.  Her store is open from eight in the morning and remains open until eight in the evening, every day.

Leoncie will use this loan to purchase more green bananas to sell.  She hopes to use any profits that she makes to purchase a fridge and start a new business selling cold soft drinks.

The Cophecomba group thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase green bananas to sell

loans.name: Damaris Njeri

texts.en:
Damaris, 39, is married to Stephen who contributes to the family income. They have three children. She has been in this business for about two years now with an income of about Kshs. 7,900  per month.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD and she plans to use the loan to buy textile material for making clothes and to buy thread.She hopes to build her own house after buying a piece of land and give her children quality education.

loans.use: To buy textile material for making clothes and to buy thread.

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Prum P. lives in Kampong Chhnang province. With her husband, she has been working her fishing boat since 2006. She and her family found that their lives are taking one step toward a healthy family. She has four single children under her roof.  The oldest is working at a garment factory with a salary of $ 100 per month. She is now asking for a loan of US$ 1100 to build another two rooms for her children. In the near future, she and her husband plan to buy a car to take her fish from the river to the market place.  She wants her children finish their university degrees.

loans.use: To build another two rooms for her children

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan K. is a widower who lives with his school-going child in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a local trader of local natural seasoning products. Recently he bought a plot of land in the village.  He is looking for a loan of US$ 400 to pay for this purchase. He dreams of becoming a major seller of local products in a bigger place.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land in the village

loans.name: Abadacogora Group

texts.en:
Francine is 28 years old.  She is married with 4 children, aged between 3 and 10. Francine’s husband is a driver.  They both work for their family's well-being. 

Francine is the leader of the group which is called Abadacogoro in the local language. This group contains 3 members: three women.

Francine has one year of experience selling various styles of clothing and shoes. Her shop is open from 8 in the morning until 5:30 in the evening every day.

Francine and her group have requested a loan to help grow their businesses by purchasing more products for their shops.  Francine hopes to earn more profits, which will allow her to save money for the future and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: C2383 Abateranankunga Group

texts.en:
Alphonse is 33 years old and is married with three children. He is the president of a group called “Abaterankunga” and this group has a range of businesses selling clothes, foodstuffs, gasoline, charcoal, etc. Alphonse is a hardworking and happy man who owns a small business that sells charcoal.

Alphonse will use this loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. He would like to use any profits to continue to grow his business.

The Abaterankunga group thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Khadicha

texts.ru: Ашурова Хадыча жительница города Душанбе. Ей 52 года. Замужем, имеет двоих сыновей. Муж, повар (ошпаз). Он готовить плов на больших мероприятиях. Старший сын занимается строительными работами, а другой студент. Сама Хадыча работает на рынке "Зеленый базар". Она арендует торговую точку, где продает детскую одежду. Этим видом деятельности занимается 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Khadicha A. is a resident of Dushanbe.  She is 52 years old, married, and has two sons.  Her husband is a cook (specifically, one who cooks traditional Tajik pilaf).    He makes pilaf for large events.  Her elder son works in construction and the other is a student.  Khadicha works in the market called “Green Bazaar."   She rents a shop where she sells children's clothes.  She has been doing this work for five years.  She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of her inventory.

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Suos

texts.en: Mrs. Suos Y. is a local farmer from Kompong Chhang Province.  She is married to Nhem Sokhom and has six children who are all single.  She is looking for a loan of US$ 500 to be used on a small transport truck and to decorate her house. She wants to become a groceries seller and wants her children to finish bachelor degrees.

loans.use: To be used on a small transport truck and decorate her house

loans.name: C2855 Abisunganye Group

texts.en:
Francois is 27 years old and married with two children and two dependents.  He is the president of a group called “Abisunganye” and they all own separate businesses selling a variety of goods including spare parts, secondhand clothing, foodstuffs, etc. Francois sells spare parts for bicycles.

Francois would like to use this loan to help build a small shop from which to run his business. Any profits from the improved business will be used to pay school fees and provide for the basic needs of his family.

Abisunganye Group thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more produce and build a small shop.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 25 years old and she is married. Jeanne sells clothing for women. This is her second successful year in this business, which she runs from 6 am until 6 pm every day.

Jeanne will use this loan to buy more clothes for men and children.  She believes this will increase her sales and she hopes to use the profits to renovate her house and look after the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy men's and children's clothes to sell.

loans.name: C2897 Abatiganda Group

texts.en:
Angelique is the representative of a group called Abatiganda.  She was born in 1985 and is married with one child. In the picture, she the first person on the right.

Angelique sells different kinds of clothes. The hours of her business are from six in the morning until six in the evening every day. This is her 5th successful year in his business where she employs one person.

Angelique will use this loan to purchase a variety of clothes to help increase profits. She would like to save any profits she makes for her child's future.

Each of the four members pictured have a different business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 31 years old and is married with two children, ages one and four. She sells beauty and other cosmetic products. Beatrice has been in this business for about three years and her store is open from 6 am to 8pm every day except on Saturday and she currently employs two people.

Beatrice will use this loan to expand her business by adding more products.  Any profits made from the use of this loan will be reinvested in her business to help it continue to do well.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetic and beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Safy

texts.fr: Madame Safy B. est une commerçante âgée de 33 ans qui vie avec son mari et ses enfants sis sur la photos dans un quartier populaire de Mbour. Son activité principale est la commercialisation de fruits et légumes et quelques fois du poisson frais  dans localités pour éviter à certains déplacements aux femmes ménagères. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ses activités en l'octroi de stock de marchandises suffisantes à son exploitation
texts.en: Mrs. Safy B. is a merchant who is 33 years old. She lives with her husband and with their children, seen here in the photo. They live in the famous quarter of Mbour. Her business is the sale of fruits and vegetables although sometimes she also sells fresh fish to private homes to cater to housewives. She requests this loan to support her business with the purchase of quantities of merchandise for resale.

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 27 years old and is married. He has been selling bags for three years.  His business is open from 6 am to 6 pm except on Saturday. He currently employs one other person in his business.

Samuel will use this loan to expand his business by purchasing bags in his village.  With these additional goods, Samuel hopes to earn more profits which will allow him to start saving for further reinvestment in his business.

loans.use: To buy bags to sell

loans.name: Gabin

texts.en:
Gabin is 26 years old and is still single. He has been selling soft drinks for two years. His business is open from early in the morning, 8 am, until late in the evening, 11pm, every day. He currently employs 6 people in his business.

Gabin will use this loan to purchase soft drinks and local beer, which are very popular.  As a young entrepreneur he plans to use any profit made to reinvest and grow his business.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks and beer to sell

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive is 24 years old and is married with three children between 3 and 7 years old. Olive sells local traditional beer. She has been in this business for about four years and  she currently employs 3 people.

Olive will use this loan to help improve her business profits by buying more sorghum to make the traditional local beer.  With any profits she hopes to reinvest back into the business to help make it grow and also build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum to make traditional beer.

loans.name: Donatille

texts.en:
Donatille is 33 years old and is married with five children who are between 5 and 15 years old. She sells beans, Irish potatoes, and other vegetables. Donatille has been in this business for about four years and employs two people.

Donatille would like to use this loan to purchase more foodstuffs such as sugar and other popular items like beer.  She would like to buy a large amount in order to wholesale to other store owners.  With any profits Donatille plans to build a shop for her business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Unity Ii Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very please to present to you the members of the Unity II Group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of SLL 800,000.00 each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Abu Bakarr B. is the leader of this group. 29-year-old Abu Bakarr is single and has no children. Abu Bakarr manages a telephone/mobile phone booth. He sells top-up cards for all four mobile companies in his booth. People also make calls in his booth for a fee of SLL 1,000. They also recharge their mobile phones in his booth for a fee of SLL 1,000 as there is no power grid in the city. He has been managing this business for twelve years now. 

With his share of this loan, he will buy mobile phone accessories such as charges, batteries, etc. and top-up cards for all four mobile phone companies. 

(Also included in the right of the photo is loan officer Daniel B. Brima)

loans.use: Buy mobile phone accessories, such as chargers, batteries, etc., and top-up cards for all four mobile phone companies

loans.name: Ignace

texts.en:
Ignace is 35 years old and is married with five children aged between three and 13. He owns a small general store which he has had for about two years. The hours of his business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day, except on Saturday. 

He currently employs three people in his business.

Ignace will use his loan to buy new products like washing powder, umbrellas, washing cloths, etc.  

He would like to use any profits that he makes to pay for his children's school fees and save for their future.

loans.use: To purchase more products like washing powder, umbrellas, washing cloths, etc.

loans.name: Quezie

texts.en:
Quezie is 32 years old, married and has five children between one and 11 years old. 

Quezie has a small general store that sells a variety of items used by all Rwandans in their homes.  She has been in this business for about three years and currently employs two people.

Quezie will use this loan to buy popular items like cooking oil, soap and sugar.  

She plans to continue investing any profits back into her business to make sure it grows and does well.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil, soap, sugar and other items to sell

loans.name: Liberathe

texts.en:
Liberathe is 38 years old, married with eight children aged between three and 18 years. Liberathe sells a local traditional beer in the Rugarama District in Rwanda. She has been in this business for about six years. The hours of her small bar are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day, except on Saturdays. 

She currently employs three people in her business.

Liberathe will use this loan to buy more sorghum for making local traditional beer. 

With this loan, Liberathe hopes also to improve the quality of service in her bar. If it is completely successful, Liberathe will start saving for her future.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum to make traditional beer

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 42 years old and married with six children aged between six and 16. Jacqueline owns a pub in the Nyagahunga Sector in Rwanda. She has been in this business for about ten years. The hours of her pub are from 7am to 9pm.

Jacqueline will use this loan to purchase more sorghum to make traditional local beer.  She would like to make a profit and use this to continue to improve and build her business.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum to make traditional beer

loans.name: Moussa

texts.en:
Moussa is 40 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 12 and 21 years old. He lives in the Kimironko district where he owns a shop selling a variety of goods. His business is open from 7:30 am until 9 pm every day. Mousse has ten years experience in retail.

Moussa will use this loan to buy more items to sell in his general store. He hopes that this will increase his profits so he can provide all the needs for his family.

loans.use: To  purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 39 years old and is married with four children between ages 6 and 14.  Elizabeth is well-known in her area for selling cosmetics, mainly body lotion. This is her third year in this business, which is open from 8 am until 7 pm every day.

Elizabeth has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by adding more cosmetic products. Her neighborhood is the right place to sell cosmetics because there are boarding schools in the area and many students who like to buy cosmetics. With this business expansion, Elizabeth will keep saving for further reinvestment in her business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Nancy Njeri

texts.en:
Nancy is a 45-year-old single mother with three children. Her horticulture farm of 10 years earns Kshs 6,000  monthly. 

She has never borrowed from any other MFI,and this is her second loan from KADET LTD, after successfully repaying the previous one. She plans to use the loan to purchase manure, pesticides, fertilizer and seedlings. She hopes to be a leading farmer and to give her children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy manure, pesticides, fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Ukuri Group

texts.en:
Gedeon is the group representative of five members who call themselves Ukuri.  Each member has a different business. Gedeon is 26 years old and single.  He owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products. The hours of his business are from six in the morning until seven in the evening every day. This is his first successful year in business.

Gedeon will use this loan to buy more products such as salt, cassava flour, bread and so on. With this loan, the group members aim to improve their family situations through saving money for their future and paying the school fees of their children.

loans.use: To purchase more general household items to sell

loans.name: Simon Njoroge

texts.en:
Simon is 52 years old and married to Joyce Wairimu, who also contributes to the family income. He has a dairy farm, which is his primary business, and he also supplies firewood as his secondary business.

He has been in this business for a period of five years, with an income of about 13,000 KES per month. He is taking a third loan from KADET LTD after successfully repaying the previous ones. He hopes to be a leading dairy farmer and give his children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy trees for firewood supply as his secondary business besides dairy farming

loans.name: Cyprien

texts.en:
Cyprien is 27 years old and married with a one-year-old child. Cyprien has been a businessman for five years and owns a small shop selling different kinds of products such as soaps, cosmetic products, water and so on. This business is profitable in this region, which is why Cyprien chose it as his principal work. The hours of his shop are from 6 in the morning until 8 in the evening, every day.

Cyprien has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business bypurchasing more products.  Cyprien would like to continue growing his business with any profits that he makes.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell.

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Greetings from Theogene in Kigali, Rwanda! Theogene is 28 years old and married.

Theogene has been a motorbike taxi driver for 6 years. He works long hours transporting people to their work places. Currently he has to rent his motorbike and he plans to use this loan to help purchase his own motorbike.  He will use any profits to help his friends and family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Adrienne

texts.fr:
Femme commerçante de 47 ans, vendeuse de friperie depuis plus de 30 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont l'age varie entre 14 et 24 ans. A l'arrêt de ses études ,Elle se lance dans la vente des serviettes,draps, peignoirs non utilises.
A l'octroi de son premier prêt, elle renforce son activité en achetant des ballots de draps, serviettes, peignoirs non portes, dans les grands magasins de la place.Ses recettes ont augmentes de 25.000frs a 125.000 fr par jour, elle a rembourse avec succès et a fait des bénéfices  considérables. 
 Avec le second prêt , elle tient a renforcer et élargir son activité en refaisant les mêmes achats, acheter des ballots de serviettes, séries de draps non utilises, des peignoirs non utilises pour satisfaire sa clientèle.
Tres dynamique , elle tient très ferme dans ses ambitions , elle pense pour ce deuxième prêt, épargner plus qu'avant, faire des grandes bénéfices pour pouvoir atteindre ses objectifs, devenir une grossiste et ouvrir une boutique  de habits de second main .Avec fierté , elle contribue a l'épanouissement de sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady is a merchant. She is 47 years old and has been selling second hand clothing for over thirty years. She is married and the mother of four children whose ages range from 14 to 24. After her studies, she started selling unused towels, bed sheets and robes.

She used her first loan to strengthen her activity by buying bundles of unused sheets, towels and robes from the large stores of the area. Her revenue increased from 25,000 to 125,000 francs per day. She fully repaid the loan and earned substantial profits.

With the second loan, she wants to strengthen and expand her activity with similar purchases. She will buy bundles of unused towels, sheets and robes to meet customer demand.

A very dynamic person, she is highly focused on her objectives. She hopes that this second loan will help boost her savings and increase her profits so that she can achieve her goal of becoming a wholesaler and opening a second hand clothing store. She is proud to be able to provide for her family’s well-being.

loans.use: Purchase bundles of unused towels, robes, and bed sheets

loans.name: Jane Njeri

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and married to Thuo, who also contributes to the family income. She runs a retail shop in Landless Thika county. She has been in the business for a period of two years, with an income of about 5,000 KES per month.

This is her third loan from KADET LTD, after successfully repaying the previous ones. Jane plans to use the loan amount to stock polythene bags, children's wear, food stove accessories, and beverages to sell. She hopes to manage a wholesale shop and give her children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To stock polythene bags, children's wear, food stove accessories, and beverages

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is a thirty-seven-year-old hardworking woman, married to an engineer with four children living in her own house in Fort Portal Uganda with a dream of securing sustainable income for the family. For four years she has been selling food and her major challenge is price fluctuation although she still wants to own a store of food and operate from one area. Harriet intends to use the credit facility to cultivate and also transport her produce for sale.

loans.use: Cultivating and transporting her produce for sale

loans.name: Alphajor

texts.en: Here is Alphajor J., a small-scale businessman in Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. Alphajor sells jeans, T-shirts, underwear, bed sheets, portmanteaus, shoes, radios, etc. He has been doing this business for ten years now. With a loan of SLL 4,000,000, Alphajor will be able to buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to his current stock. Alphajor is married to a businesswoman and they have three children – two in primary school and one in secondary school.

loans.use: Buy products for re-sale

loans.name: Benedict

texts.en: Benedict is a fifty-nine -year -old married man living in his own house with twelve children in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has a bar and also does commercial farming which has facilitated him in providing for the family since the responsibility is his alone. Benedict needs the loan to purchase beer as the festive season is fast approaching.

loans.use: Purchasing beers for sale

loans.name: Peluce

texts.en: Peluce is a forty-two-year-old single mother of two children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda longing to build her own home in  the next five years. She has a primary school and has also been a farmer for ten years now and the school is enrolling more and more pupils. Her major challenge is the failure of parents to pay promptly. Peluce needs the loan to renovate her school.

loans.use: Renovating the school

loans.name: Rosine

texts.fr:
Femme commerçante de 40 ans, célibataire et mère de 2 enfants dont l'age varie entre 16 et 20 ans .En 1993, étant déjà fille mère, elle arrête ses études en classe de première et se lance dans la vente des fournitures scolaires pour prendre soin de ses enfants.
Ayant bénéficie d'un premier prêt,il y a quatre mois,il renforce son activité en achetant des cartons de cahiers, des cartons de feuille rames; des cartons de stylos, feutres , crayons de différents couleurs .
Ses recettes ont augmentes de 30.000f a 100.000 fr par jour, puisque son lieu de vente se situe entre des administrations en plein centre ville et un complexe scolaire.
Elle a rembourse son prêt sans difficulté et a eu a faire des épargnes considérables.

Avec le second prêt , elle va aller dans la même perspective en élargissant son activité et renforcer le stock de 
 ses marchandises ,tout en satisfaisant les besoins de ses clients et en faisant plus des bénéfices énormes. 

Cliente très remarquable par son bon caractère ,sa promptitude et sa régularité dans le lieu de remboursement, elle tient a aller jusqu'au bout pour atteindre ses objectifs
texts.en:
A 40-year woman, single with two children, 16 and 20 years of age. In 1993,  already a single young mother, she abandoned her high school studies because of the need to provide for her children abd started a business selling office and school supplies. 

With her first loan, four months ago, she replenished her stock, purchasing notebooks, reams of papers, boxes of  ballpoint pens, markers, and pencils of various colors.  Her sales have increased from 30,000 to 100,000 West African Francs per day, as her stand is located  downtown, in an area with many    offices and  a school building. She repaid her loan without any issues and was able to put away substantial savings. WIth this second loan, she is going to continue the strategy of expanding her business by reinforcing her merchandise stock, meeting her clients' needs and achieving significant revenues. This client  stands out by being reliable, prompt and punctual in her payments. She is set on doing  all she possibly can to achieve her goal.

loans.use: Purchasing reams of paper, notebooks, ballpoint paints, markers, file folders, boxes of pencils

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is 45 years old and the mother of three daughters and two sons. She lives in Tulkarem City and has started a small business of producing pickles and sells them to shops and neighbors. The small project grew and became a small factory to answer the local demand.

Hanan's husband is a taxi driver. One of her sons is a Palestinian National Authority employee and her other son manages work in the factory with Hanan.

Hanan came to FATEN's office in Tulkarem, where she is pictured above, and took a loan to partly pay for a car she purchased to ease transportation and managing her work with clients as she promotes and works on partnerships with shops around the city.

loans.use: To purchase a car to help Hanan manage her work

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
53-year-old Lerma C. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has children. Lerma is engaged in farming. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells in the market. She also runs a carenderia (eatery) and cooks the food that she sells. Lerma wants her businesses to grow.

Lerma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs and ingredients for cooking.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs and ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a single lady, 30 years old and a mother of two children. She has been running a shoe business for one year. Besides shoes, she also sells some vegetables in the market. She has set up a stall where she sells onions and potatoes. Her target customers are people from the estate, since Kayole is a low- and middle-income estate with a high population, which contributes to the growth potential of her business.

Esther was introduced to KADET by a friend and member of a group she currently is in. This is her first loan, and she plans to use the money to stock more shoes for resale, especially in this month when she expects sales to go up due to the festivities.

In the future, she wants to expand her business and be able to take her children to the best schools.

loans.use: To add stock to the shoe business

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena G. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 8 children. She is engaged in farming and hog-raising. She plants and harvests rice and corn crops. She fattens the pigs she grows and sells them to the market. Magdalena happily shares that she also owns and manages a sari-sari store now. She sells products like sugar, vinegar and other things. 

Magdalena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs, feeds and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs, feed and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Manjula

texts.en:
Manjula S. is a forty-year-old woman. She was born in Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. Manjula is married and has three children. Her husband is a health inspector and two of her children are attending primary school and one is in secondary school. Manjula sells toothpastes, air-fresher, drinks, powdered milk, sardines, candles, soaps, etc. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now.  

Manjula S. has requested for a loan of SLL 4,000,000.00 from Kiva field partner, Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), in order to expand her business. She will use the loan to buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock. In this way, her business will improve both in size and quality, attracting many customers into her business.

loans.use: Buy toothpaste, air-fresher, drinks, powdered milk, sardines, candles, soaps, etc. in large quantity

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 34 years old and married to John, who also contributes to the family income. They have two children. Jane has been in the knitting business for a period of six years, with an income of 10,000 KES per month.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD, and she plans to use it to stock more yarn and buttons. She hopes to open more knitting shops in the area and to manage a wholesale shop. She also hopes to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: To buy yarn and buttons

loans.name: Noime

texts.en:
Noime A. is from the town of Banga. She is 49 years old. Noime is married and has 2 children aged 19 and 17. To make a living, Noime owns & operates a farm. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Noime works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

Noime joined CEVI to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to buy fertilizers and other farm products. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: Buy fertilizers and other farm materials

loans.name: Anjelyn

texts.en:
Anjelyn N., age 50, sells curios at Kariokor market. Her customers are both Kenyan citizens and international visitors. She is married to Ndonye Kithusi, and together they have four children: Susan, Mary, and Dennis, who are over 20 years of age; and Clara, who is 10 years old and in primary school. She has been running this business for a period of seven years, and her monthly profit is 15,000 KES.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend. This loan of 50,000 KES is her third loan with KADET. With the loan, Anjelyn plans to increase her stock of curios and pay her creditors. If this loan improves her business, she will expand her business more and pay school fees for her daughter Clara.

Anjelyn's dream is to become an entrepreneur and do business internationally. She describes herself as self-motivated and hardworking.

loans.use: To increase her stock of curios and pay some creditors

loans.name: Avenir Plus Group

texts.en: Benz is a leader of a Community bank named “Avenir Plus”, which means “Future” in English and is composed of 11 microentrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. Benz, 40 years old, is the father of two children aged 4 and 7. Both attend school. He has been a micro entrepreneur since 1996. He runs a telephone booth. His business is located in eastern Kinshasa. He is working hard because his ambition is to open other telephone booths. Benz is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC who has already received seven different loans and has repaid them properly. The loan he’ll obtain next will be used to buy more prepaid cards with the aim of increasing profits. Wanting to develop and diversify his business, he decided to join one of Hope’s groups in 2009. Currently, he makes a profit of about $90 per week. Benz has succeeded with good strategies to build up permanent customers. He always talks with his customers whom he knows by name, and never runs out of stock.

loans.use: purchasing more prepaid cards to resell with the aim of generating profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally O. is a 45-year-old married woman from the town of Banga. She is into farming, hog-raising, and selling food. She and her husband maintain their farm where they plant and harvest rice, corn, and papaya. They also have a small piggery in their backyard. Sally cooks the food that she sells at her eatery. She makes sure to manage her time well between family and businesses. She says she does this all to provide for her family.

Sally joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sally has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Sally is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs and raw ingredients for cooking.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and raw ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Kindi

texts.en: Pictured here is Kindi J.. She is thirty four years old and was born in a village call Affair, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a farmer and the couple has three children. Kindi has been a businesswoman for ten years now. She sells spare parts and engine oil. With the help of this loan, Kindi will be able to buy spare parts like sprockets, outer tires, inner tubes, park lights, brake shoes, etc. in large quantity to add into her business.

loans.use: Buys spare parts like sprockets, outer tires, inner tubes, park lights, brake shoes, etc. in large quantity to add into her business

loans.name: Moreen

texts.en: Moreen is a twenty five year old single mother of three children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  She has a dream of building her own house in future. For six years she has been in retail trade and this has helped her provide for the family as the responsibility solely lies on her. Maureen needs the loan to buy sugar, soap, and salt for sale.

loans.use: Buying sugar, soap, and salt for sale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M. is 52 years old and sells clothes in the Kwa Njenga Estate which is well-populated with many customers. She has been running this business for a period of 3 years and her monthly profit is 15,000 Kenyan shillings. She is a widowed mother of five sons, all of whom are over 18 years of age. She describes herself as hard-working and persistent. 

She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. This loan of 15,000 shillings is her first with KADET and she plans to use it to buy children’s clothes and shoes to sell during the Christmas holiday. If the loan boosts her business, Josephine will expand by introducing new shoes, since she currently sells only second-hand shoes.

Josephine dreams of sending her youngest son Wilson to study at a university.

loans.use: To buy children’s clothes and shoes to sell during the Chrismas holiday.

loans.name: Vangeline

texts.en:
Vangeline S. is from the town of Banga. She is 34 years old. Vangeline is married and has 3 children aged 5, 4 and 1. She grows rice, corn, and vegetables that she sells at their town's market. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale. Vangeline works hard to provide for her family and save for her children's education.

Vangeline joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Vangeline is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs and feeds.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and feeds

loans.name: Syprose

texts.en:
Syprose O. is 46 years old and runs a hotel business at Donholm Estate, a well populated area. She is married to John Mungai and together they have five children. Syprose and her husband have also adopted three orphaned children whom they are supporting.She has been running this business for a period of 12 years and her monthly profit is 60,000 Kenyan Shillings.
